text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2023
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH3

text: Accountability to Affected People (AAP) is a collective approach that ensures the needs and interests of
label: BODY

text: people are at the center of humanitarian action. It is based on a commitment to take account of, give
label: BODY

text: account to and be held to account by the people humanitarians seek to assist.1 In their activities related to
label: BODY

text: AAP, humanitarians collect and use increasing amounts of data. Responsible data management is critical to
label: BODY

text: ensuring that these activities do not harm affected people, and is part of fulfilling the commitments related
label: BODY

text: to AAP.
label: BODY

text: This Guidance Note explores data responsibility and AAP in humanitarian action. It identifies common
label: BODY

text: data-related benefits and risks related to AAP, explains how humanitarians can implement actions from
label: BODY

text: the IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action and offers examples of joint
label: BODY

text: approaches to this work.
label: BODY

text: 1     For more on AAP in Humanitarian Action, and OCHA’s role, see: OCHA: Accountability to affected people.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH2

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH3

text: GUIDANCE NOTE: DATA RESPONSIBILITY AND
label: HH1

text: ACCOUNTABILITY TO AFFECTED PEOPLE IN
label: HH1

text: HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH2

text: •	 Data responsibility is the safe, ethical and effective management of personal and non-personal
label: BODY

text: data for operational response and is therefore central to the humanitarian system’s
label: BODY

text: Accountability to Affected People (AAP).
label: BODY

text: •	 Examples of data management related to AAP include communicating with communities,
label: BODY

text: processing complaints and feedback, and tracking community perceptions.
label: BODY

text: •	 Collecting data from and about communities can lead to improved understanding of the
label: BODY

text: priorities and preferences of affected people, as well as their increased participation in and
label: BODY

text: ownership of humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: •	 However, data management related to AAP might carry risks, including, among others, exposure
label: BODY

text: of sensitive data that could lead to harm for affected people or humanitarian workers, and loss of
label: BODY

text: trust between affected people, humanitarian organizations and stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarians should conduct data impact assessments, design for data responsibility, develop
label: BODY

text: data management diagrams, maintain a data management registry, establish data sharing
label: BODY

text: agreements, and introduce data incident management procedures.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2023
label: BODY

text: 2     Statement by Principals of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) on Accountability to Affected People in Humanitarian Action.
label: BODY

text: 3     IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action (2023).
label: BODY

text: 4     A data management activity is any activity involving the management of data and information as part of humanitarian response. This includes the
label: BODY

text: design of the activity, as well as the collection, receipt, storage, quality assurance, analysis, sharing, use, retention and destruction of data and
label: BODY

text: information by humanitarian actors. IASC Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action (2023).
label: BODY

text: 5     Information Ecosystem Analysis seeks to capture all dimensions of the relationship between information supply and information demand. For
label: BODY

text: more information, see: Internews, Information Ecosystem Analysis - A Human-Centered Approach (2021).
label: BODY

text: 6     For more information, see the Centre for Humanitarian Data’s Tip Sheet on Understanding Data Ecosystems.
label: BODY

text: DATA MANAGEMENT RELATED TO AAP
label: HH3

text: Through AAP, humanitarians aim to ensure that humanitarian action protects and preserves the rights and
label: BODY

text: dignity of people affected by crises, remains relevant and effective, leaves no one behind, and upholds
label: BODY

text: humanitarian principles.2 By recognizing that crisis-affected people experience aid differently, AAP
label: BODY

text: enables humanitarians to work with affected people to ensure that their diverse needs, vulnerabilities and
label: BODY

text: capacities are centered in decision-making and programme design.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarians do this primarily through the following activities:
label: BODY

text: •	 Systematically providing timely, relevant and actionable information about the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: response, its actors and its activities to people and communities.
label: BODY

text: •	 Supporting the meaningful participation and leadership of affected people in decision-making,
label: BODY

text: regardless of sex, age, disability status and other diversities.
label: BODY

text: •	 Ensuring community feedback mechanisms are in place to enable affected people to assess and
label: BODY

text: comment on the performance of humanitarian action, and to make complaints about any issue,
label: BODY

text: including sensitive topics such as protection, gender-based violence, sexual exploitation and abuse,
label: BODY

text: fraud, corruption, racism and discrimination, environmental violations, and others.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarians increasingly use digital channels to engage with communities. As a result, large quantities
label: BODY

text: of data can be collected and used, requiring appropriate management. Data responsibility — the safe,
label: BODY

text: ethical and effective management of personal and non-personal data for operational response — is critical
label: BODY

text: to these efforts.3 Ensuring that data management activities4 do not harm affected people is part of fulfilling
label: BODY

text: the commitments related to AAP.
label: BODY

text: Common data management activities related to AAP include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Communicating with communities through the provision of timely and relevant information.
label: BODY

text: •	 Mechanisms for collecting, analyzing, referring and actioning complaints and feedback.
label: BODY

text: •	 Systems for tracking community perceptions, rumors, and misinformation, disinformation and hate
label: BODY

text: speech (MDH).
label: BODY

text: •	 Information management activities to inform the delivery and coordination of assistance, including
label: BODY

text: joint needs assessments and analysis, perception surveys, and mapping the presence and activities of
label: BODY

text: partners in different locations.
label: BODY

text: •	 Information ecosystem analysis5 to capture the relationship between information supply and
label: BODY

text: information demand to and from communities.
label: BODY

text: Understanding how these activities relate to one another and how data moves between individuals,
label: BODY

text: communities and organizations is part of a responsible and accountable approach to data management.6
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2023
label: BODY

text: 7    For more information, see this Guidance Note on Data Impact Assessments.
label: BODY

text: BENEFITS AND RISKS OF DATA MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES RELATED TO AAP
label: HH3

text: Understanding and balancing the benefits and risks of data management is a key component of data re-
label: BODY

text: sponsibility. Benefits and risks related to data managements activities related to AAP vary across contexts,
label: BODY

text: and may include the following common benefits and risks:
label: BODY

text: Common benefits:
label: BODY

text: •	 Improved understanding of priorities and preferences of affected people, such as their preferred
label: BODY

text: channels to receive and submit information.
label: BODY

text: •	 Increased participation in and ownership of humanitarian action by affected people.
label: BODY

text: •	 Gains in effectiveness of humanitarian action by responding to community feedback.
label: BODY

text: •	 Enhanced transparency and accountability.
label: BODY

text: Common risks:
label: BODY

text: •	 Accidental or intentional exposure of personal or non-personal sensitive data that could lead to
label: BODY

text: re-identification, retaliation, stigmatization, violence or other forms of harm for affected people.
label: BODY

text: •	 Potential misuse of data for non-humanitarian purposes. For instance, this may occur when a
label: BODY

text: commercial software vendor that provides a community communication channel uses the chat history
label: BODY

text: to pursue their own business purposes.
label: BODY

text: •	 Biased analysis leading to poor decision-making. This can happen when non-representative data from
label: BODY

text: perception surveys is used to draw response-level conclusions.
label: BODY

text: •	 Missed opportunities to use available data when efforts are not coordinated, which can lead to data
label: BODY

text: collection fatigue by affected communities and individuals having to re-share the same difficult
label: BODY

text: stories.
label: BODY

text: •	 Loss of trust between affected people, humanitarian organizations and other stakeholders when
label: BODY

text: sensitive data is released or leaked.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDED ACTIONS FOR DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN AAP
label: HH2

text: Data responsibility requires the implementation of actions at different levels of a humanitarian response,
label: BODY

text: in-line with the IASC Operational Guidance. The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’) recommends
label: BODY

text: the following actions to support data responsibility as part of AAP:
label: BODY

text: •	 Conduct a data impact assessment
label: HH3

text: •	 Design for data responsibility
label: BODY

text: •	 Develop data management diagrams
label: BODY

text: •	 Maintain a data management registry
label: BODY

text: •	 Establish data sharing agreements
label: BODY

text: •	 Introduce data incident management procedures
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2023
label: BODY

text: 8    A Data and Information Sensitivity Classification is part of an Information Sharing Protocol (ISP), which serves as the primary document of reference
label: BODY

text: governing data and information sharing in the response. The Classification indicates the level of sensitivity of different types of data and information
label: BODY

text: for a given context. This is a key component of an ISP and should be developed through a collective exercise in which different stakeholders agree on
label: BODY

text: what constitutes sensitive data in their context.
label: BODY

text: 9    For more information on data incident management, see: OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data, Guidance Note: Data Incident Management (2019).
label: BODY

text: Conduct data impact assessments
label: BODY

text: A data impact assessment (DIA)7 aims to determine the expected impacts of a data management activity
label: BODY

text: and helps identify recommendations to mitigate the potential negative impacts. Many data management
label: BODY

text: activities related to AAP involve the management of both personal and non-personal sensitive data or make
label: BODY

text: use of new digital tools. As such, organizations should conduct a DIA before starting an activity to assess
label: BODY

text: whether the activity can be implemented responsibly.
label: BODY

text: Design for data responsibility
label: HH3

text: Designing for data responsibility means identifying ways to make data management safe, ethical and
label: BODY

text: effective. All measures for data responsibility should be outlined in a clear and replicable standard
label: BODY

text: operating procedure (SOP). An SOP should include roles and responsibilities of stakeholders involved,
label: BODY

text: tools and processes for data management, measures to prevent exposure of sensitive data, and clear
label: BODY

text: terms for data retention and destruction. In addition, an SOP should specify the purpose of the given data
label: BODY

text: management, as well as its legitimate basis, including but not limited to informed consent. The SOP should
label: BODY

text: also specify measures to uphold data subjects’ rights to be informed about how their data will be used, as
label: BODY

text: well as to interact with it, or even request its full deletion. When developing an SOP, consult the data impact
label: BODY

text: assessment for the activity to inform appropriate, feasible and robust risk mitigation measures.
label: BODY

text: Develop data management diagrams
label: HH3

text: A data management diagram offers a visual understanding of an activity and can help identify gaps in
label: BODY

text: data sharing, legal provisions, infrastructure or guidance (e.g., this should be done when planning the
label: BODY

text: information flows within a Community Feedback Mechanism).
label: BODY

text: Maintain a data management registry
label: HH3

text: A data management registry provides a summary of the key data management activities led by different
label: BODY

text: actors in the response context, including the data managed in those activities. The registry should indicate
label: BODY

text: the sensitivity level for each data type, and should align with existing data and information sensitivity
label: BODY

text: classifications for the response context where available.8 It should be updated on a rolling basis by the
label: BODY

text: relevant interagency mechanism (e.g. the AAP Working Group).
label: BODY

text: Establish data sharing agreements
label: HH3

text: When sharing personal or highly sensitive data, organizations should establish a data sharing agreement
label: BODY

text: (DSA). A DSA establishes the terms and conditions that govern the sharing of specific personal data and
label: BODY

text: sensitive non-personal data between two or more parties. Check whether the data sharing is subject to
label: BODY

text: a specific data protection framework (e.g. if one of the partners is subject to national legislation). In that
label: BODY

text: case, the DSA needs to adhere to the requirements specified in the applicable data protection framework,
label: BODY

text: including relevant data subject rights and requests. A DSA may not be required if dedicated clauses on
label: BODY

text: data sharing are included in broader agreements, such as memorandums of understanding and service
label: BODY

text: contracts.
label: BODY

text: Introduce data incident management procedures
label: HH3

text: Data incidents related to AAP include exposure of data (‘data breach’) that could lead to retaliation,
label: BODY

text: stigmatization, violence or other forms of harm for affected people, and the misuse of affected people’s data
label: BODY

text: for non-humanitarian purposes. Data incident management refers to the processes and tools for identifying,
label: BODY

text: resolving, tracking and communicating about data incidents.9 It is a key component of transparent and
label: BODY

text: accountable data management, and can help prevent future incidents. Organizations should establish a
label: BODY

text: standard operating procedure for data incident management, and a registry or log to track data incidents
label: BODY

text: and how they were handled. Where the data incident constitutes a personal data breach, organizations need
label: BODY

text: to fulfill obligations established in the relevant data protection framework and in applicable data sharing
label: BODY

text: agreements. This may include providing information about the breach to individuals whose personal
label: BODY

text: data was exposed.
label: BODY

text: OCHA CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: AUGUST 2023
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’),  together with key partners, is publishing a series of guidance
label: BODY

text: notes and tip sheets on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2022 and 2023. The
label: BODY

text: guidance note series continues work initiated in 2019 and 2020. It also complements the Inter-Agency Standing
label: BODY

text: Committee Operational Guidance on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action (revised in April 2023) and the
label: BODY

text: OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines (October 2021). Through the series, the Centre aims to provide additional
label: BODY

text: guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data responsibility in practice. The guidance notes and tip
label: BODY

text: sheets published in 2022-2023 have been made possible with the support of the Government of Switzerland.
label: BODY

text: Case Study from Afghanistan: Data Responsibility in AAP
label: BODY

text: Following the de facto authorities’ decree in December 2022 banning Afghan women from working for
label: BODY

text: NGOs, the IASC established minimum criteria for programming, including robust commitments around
label: BODY

text: AAP. The AAP Working Group (AAP WG) launched the Afghanistan Community Voices and Accountability
label: BODY

text: Platform to help humanitarians collect, analyze and respond to community feedback across the response
label: BODY

text: in Afghanistan in a timely and secure manner.
label: BODY

text: Given the sensitivity of the data shared through the collective platform, the AAP WG took steps to ensure
label: BODY

text: data responsibility by design. This included conducting a data impact assessment to identify and mitigate
label: BODY

text: data-related risks, and establishing a standard operating procedure (SOP) for data management by all
label: BODY

text: partners involved. The SOP specifies that no personal data should be stored within the platform. It also
label: BODY

text: includes steps to ensure that data management within the platform does no harm, and promotes equality
label: BODY

text: and non-discrimination. This is achieved through collective analysis of complaints and feedback received
label: BODY

text: from affected communities, and the presentation of key insights in a neutral and impartial manner. The
label: BODY

text: SOP is aligned with the system-wide Information Sharing Protocol for Afghanistan, which was endorsed
label: BODY

text: by the Humanitarian Country Team in May 2023.
label: BODY

text: Case Study from Syria: Data Responsibility in Managing Community Feedback
label: BODY

text: The AAP WG developed data management diagrams to inform the expansion of the hotline. These
label: BODY

text: diagrams visualized the flow of data and information between the different actors involved. This allowed
label: BODY

text: the AAP WG to identify points for improvement in handling complaints and feedback data.
label: BODY

text: These improvements will be incorporated into an SOP for the joint hotline, which will build on the best
label: BODY

text: practices of the existing PSEAH hotline. Measures for data responsibility will include restricting access to
label: BODY

text: sensitive data, requiring the use of encrypted channels for transferring data, and defining a data retention
label: BODY

text: and destruction schedule for sensitive data once it is no longer needed to fulfill the purpose of the hotline.
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in promoting data responsibility in the design and
label: BODY

text: delivery of AAP with the Centre via centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY
